content.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

31.II.1	The Joint Inspection Unit is mandated, through its statute, as contained in General Assembly resolution 31/192, to review matters bearing on the efficiency of services and the proper use of funds and to provide an independent view aimed at improving management and methods and at achieving greater coordination among the organizations of the United Nations system. The Unit performs inspections and evaluations and issues reports and notes in which it identifies best practices, proposes benchmarks and facilitates information-sharing among all the organizations of the United Nations system that have adopted its statute.
Programme of work
Objective
31.II.2	The objective, to which the Joint Inspection Unit contributes, is to improve the efficiency, effectiveness and coordination of the United Nations system.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
31.II.3	To contribute to the objective, the Joint Inspection Unit will:

(a)	Ensure that its programme of work includes system-wide reviews in the identified main thematic areas: accountability and oversight functions and systems; management and administration practices; the implementation of policies, strategies and programmes, as well as coordination and collaboration on the realization of internationally agreed development goals, such as the Sustainable Development Goals; and governance arrangements and mechanisms, as well as inter-agency coordination;

(b)	Undertake system-wide reviews of the management and administration practices and methods of the organizations of the United Nations system in the areas of human and financial resources, administration, results-based management, strategic planning and management, change management, risk management, security and safety and information technology;
(c)	Focus on system-wide issues that can be assessed across all or multiple organizations in conducting its reviews, as well as management and administrative reviews of individual organizations;
(d)	Develop and implement effective platforms for the sharing of good practices and knowledge in the various thematic areas of the work of the Unit;

(e)	Analyse the acceptance and implementation of the Unit’s recommendations to establish how rates of acceptance and implementation can be improved and how consideration of the Unit’s reports by legislative organs can be more effective.
31.II.4	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Better information for legislative body decision-making;
(b)	Improved efficiency and effectiveness of the organizations of the United Nations system;
(c)	Improved coordination and collaboration of the organizations of the United Nations system.

31.II.5	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the planning assumption that participating organizations fully cooperate with the reviews of the Joint Inspection Unit and that recommendations are accepted and implemented.

31.II.6	With regard to coordination and cooperation within the United Nations system, the Unit will continue its engagement in various forums, including with the Board of Auditors, the Office of Internal Oversight Services and the audit and oversight committees of participating organizations. The engagement of a broad range of actors, including those beyond the traditional inspection sphere, is critical to mobilizing effective responses and pursuing solutions to improve business processes. This means the continued strengthening of existing partnerships with independent internal oversight entities and oversight committees in participating organizations, but also pursuing new ones that can help to foster innovative approaches. The Unit will pursue measures to continue to promote an integrated approach to support the implementation of the recommendations included in its reports.

31.II.7	The Joint Inspection Unit integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. The Unit will continue to examine and report on the gender policies and practices of organizations that it has identified for its management and administration reviews.

31.II.8	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Joint Inspection Unit will also continue to accelerate the effective mainstreaming of disability inclusion, including mitigating measures to overcome any challenges while operationalizing disability inclusion.
Programme performance in 2024
Greater visibility and transparency in the selection of review topics

31.II.9	During the Unit’s self-assessment exercise, participating organizations were consulted extensively. One of the observations recorded was that a more structured assessment of topics, using a set of explicit criteria, was needed as a basis for choosing the system-wide topics for review. The Unit developed selection criteria to assess the Unit’s topics that included risk, priority, value for money and coordination enhancement, and also developed a scoring template to record inspectors’ assessment of topics against the criteria. The criteria and scoring template were approved by inspectors and added as an annex to the internal working procedures. The application of the selection criteria in 2024 for the 2025 programme of work assures participating organizations and stakeholders of an objective basis for topic selection.
31.II.10	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 31.II.1).
Table 31.II.1
Performance measure

table_content.text: Greater visibility and transparency for participating organizations in the selection of review topics

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: timely availability of reviews to enable appropriate action by participating organizations to implement recommendations – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
31.II.11	The Unit’s work contributed to the availability of 100 per cent of reviews carried over from the previous year, which met the planned target.
31.II.12	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 31.II.I).
Figure 31.II.I
Performance measure: availability of reviews carried over from the previous year (annual)
(Percentage)

Result 2: enhanced management of administrative and programmatic issues by organizations of the United Nations system through the implementation by the Joint Inspection Unit of strategic and operational recommendations – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

31.II.13	The Unit’s work contributed to the improved usefulness and impact of the Unit’s reports for the organizations of the United Nations system, through the improved formulation of recommendations that better identified the required elements (i.e. what, by whom, when and for what result/impact) and through the establishment of a process for participating organizations to provide inputs on draft recommendations, which met the planned target.
31.II.14	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 31.II.2).
Table 31.II.2
Performance measure

table_content.text: Improved usefulness and impact of Joint Inspection Unit reports for organizations of the United Nations system through more efficient and enhanced data collection and data analytics

Improved usefulness and impact of the Unit’s reports for organizations of the United Nations system through improved formulation of recommendations that better identified the required elements (i.e. what, by whom, when and for what result/impact)

Improved usefulness and impact of the Unit’s reports for organizations of the United Nations system through outreach and communications to ensure that the results of its reports are disseminated across the United Nations system organizations and to Member States
Improved reporting on the acceptance, implementation and intended impact of the Unit’s recommendations by organizations of the United Nations system

children.text: Result 3: strengthened impact of Joint Inspection Unit recommendations – Proposed programme plan for 2026

31.II.15	The value and impact of the recommendations made in the Unit’s products (reports and notes) are realized when they are accepted and implemented by the participating organizations. The Unit has developed its strategic framework to focus on key intended impact areas for recommendations. The framework seeks to ensure that the Unit balances the mix of recommendations in order to have an intended impact that focuses on selected areas for the participating organizations.
Lessons learned and planned change

31.II.16	The lesson for the Unit was that it was necessary to refine the proportion and distribution of the intended impact of recommendations in order to strengthen the focus on certain identified areas. In applying the lesson, the Unit will target recommendations that will have a greater intended impact in certain areas, such as transparency and accountability; effectiveness; efficiency; and dissemination of good practices.
31.II.17	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 31.II.3).
Table 31.II.3
Performance measure: proportion of recommendations with intended impact in the identified areas

table_content.text:
26 per cent: enhanced transparency and accountability
23 per cent: enhanced effectiveness 
15 per cent: enhanced efficiency and dissemination of good practices

50 per cent: transparency, accountability, coordination, cooperation, control and compliance 
30 per cent: effectiveness, coherence and harmonization 
20 per cent: efficiency and dissemination of good practices

50 per cent: transparency, accountability, coordination, cooperation, control and compliance 
30 per cent: effectiveness, coherence and harmonization
20 per cent: efficiency and dissemination of good practices

content.text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026

children.text: Overview (jointly financed activities)
31.II.20	The proposed jointly financed resources for 2026, including the breakdown of resource changes, as applicable, are reflected in tables 31.II.5 to 31.II.7.
Table 31.II.5
Overall: evolution of financial resources by object of expenditure (jointly financed)

Table 31.II.7

a	Includes 11 temporary posts for inspectors at the D-2 level.
31.II.21	Additional details on the distribution of the proposed resources for 2026 are reflected in table 31.II.9 and figure 31.II.II.

31.II.22	As shown in table 31.II.5, the overall resources proposed for 2026 amount to $9,666,200, reflecting a net decrease of $170,400 (or 1.7 per cent) compared with the approved budget for 2025. Resource changes result from technical adjustments. The proposed level of resources provides for the full, efficient and effective implementation of mandates.

31.II.23	In accordance with article 20 of the statute of the Joint Inspection Unit, the budget estimates have been established after consultation with the Finance and Budget Network of the High-level Committee on Management of CEB conducted in March 2025. The Network reviewed the budget proposed by the Unit for 2026, following the same process as outlined in paragraph 31.I.25 above for the Commission. The Network expressed appreciation with a 26 per cent budget reduction in non-post resources proposed by the Unit, which is due to the removal of non-recurring items budgeted in 2025. The proposed resources for 2026 shown in the present budget submission are as proposed by the Unit.

31.II.24	As shown in table 31.II.9, resource changes result from technical adjustments (decrease of $170,400) under furniture and equipment, reflecting the removal of non-recurrent resources approved for 2025 for the replacement of the Unit’s web-based tracking system and the purchase of a new conferencing system.

31.II.25	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Unit will continue to reduce its carbon footprint by reducing the quantity of documentation printed, as well as by limiting travel and maximizing the use of possible alternatives to face-to-face meetings, whenever feasible.

31.II.26	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 31.II.8. The Unit requires that, for each of its review projects, a travel plan be submitted to facilitate the advance purchase of the related air tickets. Better advanced planning has enabled the Unit to be almost fully compliant with the target requiring air tickets to be purchased at least two weeks in advance of travel, thus guaranteeing lower travel costs.
Table 31.II.8
Compliance rate
(Percentage)

table_content.text: Air tickets purchased at least two weeks before the commencement of travel

children.text: 31.II.27	The proposed regular budget resources for 2026 amount to $2,631,900 and reflect a net decrease of $3,100 (or 0.1 per cent) compared with the approved budget for 2025. As reflected in table 31.II.10, resource changes result from technical adjustments and reflect a decrease of $46,400, representing the United Nations Secretariat share (27.2 per cent) of the reduction presented above under the jointly financed budget of the Unit ($170,400), offset in part by an increase in the United Nations Secretariat share of the budget of the Unit from 26.8 per cent for 2025 to 27.2 per cent for 2026 ($43,300), as determined by the CEB Secretariat in accordance with the established methodology.
